column4: Danfoss wins conditional EU okay for $3.3 billion buy of Eaton's hydraulic unit
column5: BRUSSELS (Reuters) - EU antitrust enforcers cleared on Thursday Danfoss’ $3.3 billion acquisition of Irish power management company Eaton’s hydraulic business after the Danish industrial company agreed to sell some units to address competition concerns.
column6: Danfoss and Eaton, leading players in the global hydraulic components market, announced the deal in January last year.
column7: The European Commission said Danfoss’ concessions will allay concerns that the deal may push up prices and reduce competition.
column8: Danfoss will sell some businesses in Germany, Poland and the United States, while some Eaton production lines of certain components will be transferred to the U.S. facility due to be sold off. Key technologies will also be transferred.

column4: Eaton to buy Cobham Mission Systems in $2.83 billion deal
column5: (Reuters) - Hydraulics maker Eaton Corp said on Monday it had agreed to buy air-to-air refueling equipment maker Cobham Mission Systems in a $2.83 billion deal to strengthen its aerospace business.
column6: U.S.-based Cobham mainly serves the defense sector, Eaton said.
column7: Excluding $130 million in tax benefits, Cobham’s purchase price is about 14 times its 2020 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) and 13 times its estimated 2021 EBITDA, Eaton said.
column8: Ireland-based Eaton makes products including explosion-proof instrumentation, pumps, motors and hydraulic power units.
column9: The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2021.

column4: Eaton to buy Cobham Mission Systems in $2.83 bln deal
column5: Feb 1 (Reuters) - Aerospace hydraulics maker Eaton Corp said on Monday it had agreed to buy air-to-air refueling equipment maker Cobham Mission Systems in a $2.83 billion deal. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: Insurers drop appeal against UK COVID-19 payout ruling on three policies
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - Six insurers have decided not to appeal against a London High Court ruling that they were wrong to reject claims from holders of three business interruption insurance policies who have been pushed to the brink of collapse by the COVID-19 pandemic.
column6: RSA, QBE, Hiscox, MS Amlin, Argenta and Arch were expected to challenge the judgment to pay affected customers holding five types of policy in a fast-tracked Supreme Court case to be heard by end-2020.
column7: But the appeals linked to the Resilience, Eaton Gate Retail, and Eaton Gate Pubs & Restaurants policies have now been dropped, legal documents show, raising hopes that hundreds of vulnerable businesses could see their claims processed without further delay.
column8: A spokesman for RSA, one of the largest of the six insurers, said it would work with broker Marsh to make interim payments where appropriate.
column9: Businesses across the world have been locked in disputes with insurance companies over pandemic-related payouts.
column10: Insurers say they are paying valid claims but that many policies exclude pandemics, require physical damage to premises or do not apply to widespread lockdowns, and paying out all claims could be catastrophic for the industry.
column11: “It is of course a huge win for large portions of the UK’s business community, which for so many months has been told by insurers that insurance policies do not cover losses relating to the COVID-19 pandemic; that is plainly wrong,” said Mishcon de Reya partner Sonia Campbell, on behalf of the Hospitality Insurance Group Action.
column12: Britain’s Financial Conduct Authority brought a case against a total of eight insurers in June to clarify whether 21 policy wordings, affecting potentially 700 types of policies, 60 insurers, 370,000 policyholders and billions in insurance claims, covered disruption and government-ordered closures to curb the virus.
column13: The High Court in London last month ruled that many business interruption policies did in fact provide such cover. Two of the eight insurers, Zurich and Ecclesiastical, said they had no need to appeal since the judgment already found in their favour.
column14: According to the documents, the insurers will continue to appeal the court’s findings in respect to the Cottagesure and the Eaton Gate Commercial Combined policies.
column15: (This story clarifies Zurich, Ecclesiastical found judgment as favourable.)

column4: EU to investigate Eaton's $3.3 billion sale of hydraulics unit to Danfoss
column5: BRUSSELS (Reuters) - EU antitrust regulators opened an investigation on Monday into power management company Eaton's ETN.N $3.3 billion sale of its hydraulics business to Danish industrial company Danfoss, saying the deal may reduce competition.
column6: As both are leading manufacturers of hydraulic components for mobile machinery globally, the deal would remove one of the main competitors, the European Commission said in a statement.
column7: “The transaction may lead to a reduced choice in suppliers, as well as higher prices, for certain hydraulic components for mobile applications, including hydraulic steering units, electrohydraulic steering valves, and orbital motors,” the EU competition enforcer said.
column8: It added that it had until Feb. 3 to take a decision.

column4: Signify to buy U.S. firm Cooper Lighting for $1.4 billion
column5: AMSTERDAM (Reuters) - Signify LIGHT.AS, the Dutch-based lighting company, has agreed to buy U.S. firm Cooper Lighting Solutions from Eaton Corp. [EATO.UL] for $1.4 billion in cash to boost its presence in North America.
column6: Signify shares rose 4.6% to 25.00 euros in early trading in Amsterdam after the company said the deal would add to earnings per share in the first year and lead to cost savings of $60 million annually within three years.
column7: The acquisition is the largest by Signify, the world’s largest lighting maker that was formerly known as Philips Lighting, since it was spun off from Philips in 2016.
column8: The deal aims to boost Signify's position in the global professional lighting market, where it is the No.2 player, and in North America, where it suffers from a lack of scale and competes with rivals like Acuity Brands Inc. AYI.N, CFO Stephane Rougeot said.
column9: “The rationale from a strategy standpoint is to get a much stronger market position in North America in professional,” he said in a telephone interview.
column10: “With Cooper we are getting a very large player in North America professional. They have great market positions, they have a large agent network, they have very deep customer relationships, they have great brands over there.”
column11: The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2020 pending regulatory approvals.
column12: Peachtree City, Ga.-based Cooper Lighting Solutionst sells professional lighting and controls under the Corelite, Halo, McGraw-Edison and Metalux brands.
column13: It reported 2018 sales of $1.7 billion and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $187 million.
column14: ING analyst Marc Hesselink, who rates Signify shares at “hold”, said the deal was a “good strategic fit for Signify and price paid seems reasonable.”
column15: Still, Cooper would not add technology or new capabilities to Signify’s portfolio and the deal would not really change the growth or margin profile of the company, he said.
column16: Signify said it intends to keep dividends steady or increase them after the acquisition, but its main focus will be to reduce debt of the combined company from two times net debt to EBITDA to one time in the next three years.
column17: During that time Signify will make further merger and acquisition activity less of a priority, Rougeot said.
column18: Lazard advised Signify on the deal. Eaton was advised by Goldman Sachs.

column4: Signify to buy Cooper Lighting from Eaton for $1.4 bln -statement
column5: AMSTERDAM, Oct 15 (Reuters) - Signify, the Dutch lighting company, said on Tuesday it would buy Cooper Lighting Solutions of the U.S. from Eaton for $1.4 billion in cash.
column6: The company said in a statement the acquisition would strengthen the strategic position of Signify, the world’s largest lighting maker, in North America.

column4: FDA grants Jacobus Pharma approval for rare disease drug
column5: (Reuters) - Jacobus Pharmaceutical Co Inc on Monday won U.S. approval for the first drug to treat children with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a rare autoimmune disorder.
column6: The drug, Ruzurgi, was approved for use in patients aged between 6 and 17, the FDA said here.
column7: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which affects about three people per million worldwide, affects the connection between nerves and muscles, disrupting the ability of nerve cells to send signals to muscle cells.
column8: The treatment currently available has been approved only for adults.

column4: Eaton to spin off its lighting business unit
column5: (Reuters) - U.S. industrial conglomerate Eaton Corp Plc said on Friday it would spin-off its lighting business unit, which makes LED lighting and controls, with sales of about $1.7 billion in 2018.
column6: Eaton, which makes a wide array of products ranging from filters for oil and gas industries to components for the aerospace sector, reported sales of $21.6 billion last year.
column7: The spin-off, which is aimed at creating an independent, publicly traded company, is expected to be completed by the end of 2019, Eaton said.
column8: Goldman Sachs is serving as the company’s financial adviser on the deal.
